prompt: Don Johnson is an acclaimed American actor, producer, and singer, known for his roles in Miami Vice and Nash Bridges. Please write a short biography of Don Johnson.
response:
Don Johnson was born on January 20, 1944, in Flatonia, Texas, to a family of modest means. His parents, a high school English teacher and a mechanic, instilled in him a love of music and the arts from a young age. Johnson grew up singing in the church choir and performing in school plays, and he was particularly drawn to the works of Tennessee Williams and James Dean.

After high school, Johnson moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in acting. He began landing small roles on television shows and in films, but it wasn't until he landed the lead role in the 1980s crime drama series "Miami Vice" that he gained widespread recognition. Johnson's charismatic performance as Detective James "Sonny" Crockett earned him critical acclaim and a loyal fan base.

In the 1990s, Johnson starred in the popular television series "Nash Bridges," playing the titular character and executive producing the show alongside his partner, Carlton Cuse. The series ran for six seasons and cemented Johnson's status as a television icon.

In addition to his work on screen, Johnson has also pursued a music career, releasing several albums and singles over the years. His soulful voice and eclectic style have earned him a loyal following among music fans.

Throughout his career, Johnson has been recognized with numerous awards and nominations, including multiple Golden Globe and Emmy nods. He has also been honored with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame and has been named one of the "Sexiest Men Alive" by People magazine.

Despite his success, Johnson remains humble and dedicated to his craft, continually seeking out new and challenging roles to take on. He currently resides in Miami, where he continues to act, produce, and enjoy his passion for music.

Johnson's early life was marked by a nomadic childhood, moving frequently due to his father's work as a musician and a construction worker.

Johnson began his acting career in the 1960s, landing small roles in films and television shows. He gained recognition in the 1970s with his portrayal of Dr. Doug Ross on the NBC medical drama "CHiPs" (1974-1975). However, it was his iconic role as Detective James "Sonny" Crockett in the NBC crime drama "Miami Vice" (1984-1990) that cemented his status as a Hollywood star.

Johnson's performance in "Miami Vice" earned him numerous awards and nominations, including an Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series. During this period, he also appeared in films such as "The Golden Child" (1986), "Harley Davidson and the Marlboro Man" (1991), and "Tango & Cash" (1989), opposite Sylvester Stallone.

In the 1990s and 2000s, Johnson continued to appear in a range of film and television projects, including the CBS drama series "Nash Bridges" (1996-2001), which he co-created and executive produced. He has also appeared in films such as "The Break-Up" (2006), "Machete" (2010), and "Django Unchained" (2012).

Throughout his career, Johnson has been recognized for his distinctive style, which often incorporates his signature mustache and fashion sense. He has been married twice, first to Melanie Griffith, with whom he had a daughter, Dakota Johnson, and then to Kelley Phleger, with whom he has two children.

Today, Johnson continues to act in film and television, with recent appearances in the TNT series "Banshee" (2013-2016) and the Cinemax series "Blood & Treasure" (2019-present). He has also released several albums as a singer-songwriter and has been involved in various business ventures, including a line of cigars and a coffee shop in Miami.

After dropping out of college, Johnson moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in acting.

Johnson's early roles included guest appearances on TV shows and minor film parts, but his breakout came in the late 1980s when he starred as Detective James "Sonny" Crockett in the popular TV series Miami Vice. The show's iconic style, music, and crime-fighting antics catapulted Johnson to international fame, earning him multiple awards and nominations, including a Golden Globe Award for Best Actor in a Television Series.

Following the success of Miami Vice, Johnson went on to star in the crime drama series Nash Bridges (1996-2001), playing the lead role of Inspector Dominic "Nash" Bridges, a detective with the San Francisco Police Department. Throughout the 2000s, Johnson continued to appear in various TV shows and films, including Dancing with the Stars (2009), where he won the coveted Mirror Ball Trophy.

Johnson has also explored his musical side, releasing several albums, including the self-titled Don Johnson (1987) and Heartbeat (1991). His most successful single, "Heartbeat," peaked at number 5 on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart.

Throughout his career, Don Johnson has won numerous awards and has been recognized for his humanitarian work, particularly in the area of children's education and environmental conservation. Despite his widespread fame, Johnson remains humble and dedicated to his craft, continuing to captivate audiences with his unique blend of charm, wit, and versatility.

In the 1980s, Johnson's career took a significant leap forward with the role of Detective Sonny Crockett in the popular NBC series "Miami Vice" (1984-1990). His portrayal of the charismatic and stylish Crockett, opposite Philip Michael Thomas as Detective Ricardo Tubbs, earned him widespread acclaim and a Golden Globe nomination.

Following the success of "Miami Vice," Johnson starred in the CBS series "Nash Bridges" (1996-2001), playing the title character, a San Francisco police inspector. The show ran for six seasons and further cemented Johnson's status as a leading man.

Throughout his career, Johnson has appeared in numerous films, including "Macho Callahan" (1970), "The Harrad Experiment" (1973), "The Deadly Tower" (1971), "Lone Star" (1996), "Django Unchained" (2012), and "Tangled" (2010). He has also lent his voice to several animated films and TV shows.

In addition to his acting work, Johnson has released two music albums: "Heartbeat" (1986) and "Let It Roll" (1989). His music style blends country, rock, and pop elements.

Johnson has been married twice and has four children. He has been recognized for his philanthropic efforts, particularly in the areas of environmental conservation and cancer research.

With a career spanning over five decades, Don Johnson has solidified his place as a beloved and respected figure in the entertainment industry. His iconic performances, charming persona, and dedication to his craft have made him a beloved figure to audiences around the world.
